heroDescription: Australia's Largest Bank • 53,000 Employees • 1H FY25: $5.1B Cash NPAT
heroCompanyDescription: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (ASX: CBA) is Australia's largest bank by market capitalisation and holds the #1 or #2 position across retail deposits, home lending, business banking, and digital payments. CBA serves approximately 17 million customers through a branch network, digital platforms (CommBank app with 8.7M+ monthly active users), and institutional banking. The stock trades at a persistent premium to major bank peers, reflecting franchise quality and digital leadership: but the premium has expanded to historically extreme levels at ~24x forward P/E.

skew.rationale: CBA trades at ~24x forward earnings, a 40%+ premium to NAB and ANZ, and well above its own 10-year average of ~16x. While franchise quality and digital leadership justify some premium, the current valuation leaves no margin for error. NIM compression is underway as rate cuts begin, mortgage competition is intensifying, and credit costs are likely to normalise from cyclical lows. Risk skew tilts to the downside at these elevated multiples.

verdict.text: 1H FY25 delivered cash NPAT of $5.13B, up 2% on pcp, with NIM of 1.99% (down 4bp). The franchise continues to perform: home lending grew 5.2%, business lending 8.7%, and the CommBank app now has 8.7M monthly active users. CET1 capital is strong at 12.2%. However, at ~24x forward P/E, CBA is priced for perfection in an environment where NIMs are compressing, mortgage competition is fierce, and the RBA is cutting rates. The quality is undeniable, but the price already reflects it and then some. The risk/reward is asymmetric to the downside at current levels.

featuredRationale: Highest-quality Australian bank franchise but priced at historically extreme multiples. The 40%+ P/E premium to peers leaves no room for NIM compression or credit normalisation. Quality is not in question: valuation is.

identity.overview: Australia's largest bank by market capitalisation, serving ~17 million customers across retail, business, institutional, and wealth management. CBA holds #1 or #2 market share in home loans (~25%), household deposits (~27%), and business lending. The CommBank app is Australia's most-used banking app with 8.7M monthly active users. 1H FY25 cash NPAT was $5.13B (up 2%), NIM was 1.99% (down 4bp), and CET1 capital was 12.2%. Cost-to-income ratio improved to 44.7%. The stock trades at a persistent and widening premium to peers, currently ~24x forward earnings vs peer average of ~14x.

hypotheses.title: Digital Franchise Premium: Quality Justifies the Multiple
hypotheses.description: CBA's digital-first strategy, dominant market position, and operational efficiency justify a sustained premium to peers. The CommBank app (8.7M MAU), AI-driven personalisation, and industry-leading Net Promoter Score create a flywheel of customer acquisition, retention, and cross-sell that competitors cannot easily replicate. If CBA continues to gain market share while maintaining cost discipline, the premium multiple is defensible.
requires: Home lending market share maintained at ~25%
Net Promoter Score remains #1 among majors
supporting: App dominance: CommBank app 8.7M monthly active users, #1 banking app by engagement, 2x nearest peer
Cost efficiency: Cost-to-income 44.7%, best among majors (NAB 45.8%, ANZ 49.2%, WBC 48.1%)
Cross-sell: CBA cross-sells 3.4 products per customer vs peer average of 2.8
NPS leadership: #1 or #2 NPS across all major banking segments for 12 consecutive quarters
contradicting: Valuation stretch: 24x forward P/E is 50% above 10-year average of ~16x; premium has never been this wide
Peer convergence: NAB and WBC investing heavily in digital, gap may narrow over 3-5 years
Regulatory ceiling: Market share above 25% in home lending may attract ACCC scrutiny

hypotheses.title: NIM Compression: Rate Cuts Squeeze the Franchise
hypotheses.description: The RBA rate-cutting cycle that began in February 2025 will compress CBA's net interest margin from the current 1.99%. As a deposit-heavy bank (~70% deposit-funded), CBA benefits disproportionately from higher rates, but the reverse is also true. Each 25bp rate cut could reduce NIM by 2-4bp, with full pass-through on lending but sticky savings rates limiting deposit repricing. If NIM falls to 1.85-1.90%, EPS could decline 5-8% from peak levels.
requires: Deposit switching to term deposits at higher rates persists
CBA unable to offset NIM compression with volume growth
supporting: Rate cycle turning: RBA cut 25bp in Feb 2025, market pricing 3 more cuts by mid-2026
NIM already declining: 1H FY25 NIM was 1.99%, down 4bp from 2H FY24, down 14bp from peak of 2.13%
Deposit mix shift: Transaction account share fell from 34% to 31% as customers move to term deposits
Mortgage pricing war: Macquarie, ING, Bendigo offering 50-80bp below CBA standard variable rate
contradicting: Volume offset: Home lending grew 5.2% and business lending 8.7% in 1H, partially offsetting margin pressure
Non-interest income: Trading income up 22%, wealth management fees growing, diversifying revenue
Cost discipline: Operating expenses flat in nominal terms, positive jaws providing earnings buffer

hypotheses.title: Competitive Disruption: Neo-Banks and Non-Bank Lenders
hypotheses.description: Digital-native competitors (Macquarie, ING, Up, Revolut) and non-bank lenders are taking share in specific segments. Macquarie has become the 5th-largest home lender with aggressive pricing. Buy-now-pay-later and embedded finance are disintermediating payments. Open banking (CDR) could accelerate switching. While CBA's franchise remains dominant, the competitive moat may be narrower than the valuation premium implies.
requires: Consumer Data Right (CDR) adoption reaches critical mass
CBA loses #1 market share position in any major segment
Payments disintermediation reduces transaction banking revenue
supporting: Macquarie surge: Macquarie Bank now #5 home lender by flow, winning on price with 50bp+ discount
ING growth: ING Australia home lending grew 12% in FY24, taking share from majors
BNPL penetration: Afterpay/Zip processing $15B+ annually, displacing credit card revenue
CDR rollout: Open banking data sharing now live, enabling easier switching between banks
contradicting: Scale advantage: CBA's 750 branches, 4,000 ATMs, and $1.1T balance sheet create barriers to entry
Regulatory moat: APRA licensing and capital requirements protect incumbents from fintech disruption
Customer stickiness: Average CBA customer tenure is 14 years; switching costs remain high despite CDR

hypotheses.title: Credit Cycle Normalisation: Housing Risk Re-emerges
hypotheses.description: CBA's loan impairment expense is at cyclical lows (8bp of gross loans). As the RBA cuts rates, the economy may slow further before easing takes effect. If unemployment rises above 5% or house prices correct 10%+, credit losses could normalise to 15-25bp, reducing cash NPAT by $1-2B annually. CBA's 65% mortgage book concentration makes it the most exposed major bank to a housing correction.
requires: House prices correct more than 10% nationally
Consumer stress metrics (90+ day arrears) deteriorate materially
supporting: Cyclical lows: Loan impairment at 8bp vs 15-year average of 18bp; mean reversion likely
Fixed rate cliff: $80B of CBA fixed-rate mortgages have rolled to variable rates at 200bp+ higher
Consumer stress rising: 90-day home loan arrears up from 0.46% to 0.58%, hardship applications up 30%
Housing affordability: National median dwelling price-to-income ratio at 9.3x, historically stretched
contradicting: Employment resilience: Unemployment at 4.1%, 430K jobs created in 2024, labour market remains tight
Rate cuts helping: RBA easing reduces mortgage stress; each 25bp cut saves average borrower ~$100/month
LVR discipline: CBA average LVR at origination 66%, dynamic LVR 49% due to property price gains
Provisioning buffer: $5.9B in total provisions including $1.7B economic overlay, well-capitalised for stress

narrative.theNarrative: CBA is the highest-quality bank franchise in Australia, and possibly the most expensive bank stock in the developed world. The bull case is straightforward: CBA's digital leadership (8.7M app users), cost efficiency (44.7% CTI), and dominant market position create a compounding machine that deserves a structural premium. The bear case is equally clear: at 24x forward earnings, the stock is priced for a level of perfection that banking economics cannot deliver. NIMs are compressing (1.99%, down 14bp from peak), mortgage competition is intensifying, and credit costs are at cyclical lows that must eventually normalise. The question is not whether CBA is a great franchise: it is: but whether the current price already reflects that quality and then some.

priceImplication.label: Downside Skew at Current Multiples
priceImplication.content: At 24x forward earnings, CBA is priced for flawless execution in a deteriorating margin environment. Bull case (25x, NIM holds): ~$175. Base case (20x, NIM compresses to 1.90%): ~$140. Bear case (16x, credit costs normalise): ~$110. The risk/reward is asymmetric to the downside. Even the bull case offers only ~3% upside, while the bear case implies 35% downside.

narrative.evidenceCheck: Evidence across 10 domains confirms franchise quality is intact but highlights valuation risk. Corporate communications emphasise digital leadership and cost discipline. Statutory filings show NIM declining from peak. Broker consensus is divided (7 Buy, 8 Hold, 5 Sell). Alternative data confirms app dominance but deposit mix is shifting unfavourably. Academic research on bank valuations suggests premium multiples eventually mean-revert. Governance is strong under Matt Comyn. Registry data shows passive inflows supporting price but active managers underweight.
narrative.narrativeStability: Moderate: The quality narrative is stable, but the valuation narrative is stretched. Any NIM miss, credit cost surprise, or competitive share loss could trigger a de-rating. The narrative is vulnerable to the very thing that created it: perfection is priced in, so any imperfection is punished.

evidence.intro: Cross-referencing 10 independent evidence domains to validate or challenge each hypothesis. CBA's franchise quality is well-documented across corporate, regulatory, and alternative data sources. The key tension is between undeniable operational excellence and historically extreme valuation multiples.

cards.title: 1. Corporate Communications
cards.finding:
CBA investor presentations emphasise digital leadership, cost discipline, and market share gains. 1H FY25 presentation highlighted 8.7M app users, 44.7% CTI ratio, and 5.2% home lending growth. Messaging consistently frames CBA as a technology company that happens to be a bank.
  • 1H FY25 Results (Feb 2025): Cash NPAT $5.13B (+2%). NIM 1.99% (-4bp). Home lending +5.2%, business lending +8.7%. CET1 12.2%. CEO Comyn emphasised “disciplined growth” and “digital-first customer acquisition”
  • Technology investment: $1.6B technology spend in FY24, 25% allocated to AI and data capabilities. Highlighted personalised offers driving 40% increase in digital product sales
  • Sustainability integration: Committed to net-zero financed emissions by 2050, $70B sustainable finance target by 2030 ($45B deployed to date)
  • Dividend signal: Interim dividend $2.25/share (fully franked), maintained payout ratio at 73%, signalling confidence in earnings sustainability
cards.tension: Confirms N1 (franchise quality) but corporate communications naturally emphasise positives. NIM compression and competitive threats are acknowledged but framed as manageable. Discount motivational framing by 20-30%.
cards.source: 1H FY25 Results (Feb 2025); Technology investment; Sustainability integration; Dividend signal

cards.title: 2. Regulatory Filings & Financial Statements
cards.finding:
APRA returns and audited financials reveal a well-capitalised bank with declining margins. CET1 at 12.2% is well above the 10.25% minimum. NIM trend confirms compression thesis. Loan impairment at 8bp is at cyclical lows, creating asymmetric upside risk to credit costs.
  • APRA quarterly ADI statistics (Dec 2024): CBA total assets $1.19T. Capital adequacy ratio 18.5%. CET1 12.2% (Level 2). Liquidity coverage ratio 131%. Net stable funding ratio 116%
  • NIM trajectory: 2.10% (2H FY23) → 2.13% (1H FY24, peak) → 2.03% (2H FY24) → 1.99% (1H FY25). Sequential decline accelerating
  • Credit quality: Gross impaired assets $4.3B (0.38% of total). Provision coverage 136%. Total provisions $5.9B including $1.7B collective overlay. 90-day arrears rising but from very low base
  • AUSTRAC compliance: No material regulatory actions since $700M AUSTRAC penalty (2018). Compliance systems overhauled with $500M investment
cards.tension: Statutory data confirms N2 (NIM compression is real and accelerating) and provides early warning for N4 (arrears rising from lows). Strong capital position supports franchise resilience but doesn\'t address valuation risk.

tags.text: Supports N2 (NIM compression is real and accelerating)

cards.source: APRA quarterly ADI statistics (Dec 2024); NIM trajectory; Credit quality; AUSTRAC compliance

cards.title: 3. Broker Research
cards.finding:
Broker consensus is unusually divided: 7 Buy, 8 Hold, 5 Sell. Consensus 12-month target price of ~$150 implies 12% downside from current levels. UBS and Morgan Stanley are the most bearish (targets $125-130); Macquarie and Goldman are the most bullish (targets $170-175). The split reflects genuine disagreement about whether the premium multiple is sustainable.
  • Bullish camp (Macquarie, Goldman): Argue CBA deserves structural premium due to digital moat, cost leadership, and capital-light growth. Target $170-175 based on 22-24x sustainable earnings
  • Bearish camp (UBS, Morgan Stanley): Argue premium has overshot fundamentals. NIM compression + credit normalisation = 10-15% EPS downside not priced in. Target $125-130 based on 17-18x forward earnings
  • Consensus EPS forecasts: FY25E $6.05, FY26E $5.85 (-3.3%), FY27E $5.95 (+1.7%). Consensus sees earnings trough in FY26 from NIM compression before modest recovery
  • Short interest: 1.2% of shares outstanding, low but rising from 0.8% six months ago. Some funds building short positions against the premium
cards.tension: Broker dispersion is itself a signal: when sell-side is this divided, consensus target is less reliable. The bearish arguments directly support N2 (NIM compression) and N4 (credit normalisation) hypotheses. The bullish arguments support N1 (franchise premium).
cards.source: Bullish camp (Macquarie, Goldman); Bearish camp (UBS, Morgan Stanley); Consensus EPS forecasts; Short interest

cards.title: 4. Competitor Disclosures
cards.finding:
Peer bank results and disclosures provide independent validation of industry trends. NAB, ANZ, and WBC all report similar NIM compression dynamics. Macquarie Bank\'s aggressive mortgage pricing confirms N3 competitive threat. Peer cost-to-income ratios confirm CBA\'s efficiency leadership.
  • NAB FY24: NIM 1.71% (down 10bp). Cash ROE 11.3%. Home lending growth 4.8%. CEO noted “intense competition in home lending” and “margin pressure from deposits repricing”
  • ANZ FY24: NIM 1.55% (down 12bp). Suncorp integration ongoing. Mortgage market share gained 30bp to 14.8%. Flagged deposit pricing as key headwind
  • WBC FY24: NIM 1.81% (down 5bp). Best improvement among majors due to UNITE simplification program. Home lending growth lagging at 3.1%
  • Macquarie Bank: Home lending grew 18% in FY24, now #5 by flow. Offering 50-80bp below standard variable rates. Using wealth platform to cross-sell mortgages
cards.tension: Peer data independently confirms N2 (NIM compression is industry-wide, not CBA-specific) and N3 (Macquarie disruption is real). CBA\'s relative NIM performance is better than peers, supporting N1 franchise quality thesis.

tags.text: Supports N2 (NIM compression is industry-wide, not CBA-specific)
Neutral on N3 (Macquarie disruption is real)

cards.source: NAB FY24; ANZ FY24; WBC FY24; Macquarie Bank

cards.title: 5. Economic Data
cards.finding:
RBA monetary policy, ABS employment data, and housing market statistics provide the macro backdrop. Rate cuts support mortgage volumes but compress NIMs. Labour market remains resilient but is softening. House prices near record highs but affordability is stretched.
  • RBA cash rate: Cut 25bp to 4.10% in February 2025. Market pricing 3 more cuts to 3.35% by mid-2026. Each cut reduces CBA NIM by estimated 2-4bp
  • ABS labour force (Jan 2025): Unemployment 4.1%, underemployment 6.3%. Employment growth slowing to +15K/month (from +35K in 2024). Leading indicators (job ads -8% yoy) suggest gradual softening
  • CoreLogic Home Value Index (Jan 2025): National dwelling values +4.2% yoy. Sydney +3.1%, Melbourne -1.8%, Brisbane +9.5%. Listings rising 12% yoy, time on market increasing
  • ABS credit aggregates: Housing credit growth 5.3% yoy (strongest since 2022). Business credit 7.8% yoy. System credit growth supporting bank volumes but competitive dynamics splitting the pool
cards.tension: Economic data confirms the macro setup for N2 (rate cuts compressing NIMs) and provides base-case support for N4 (labour market softening but not breaking). House price resilience to date contains credit risk but affordability stretch is a medium-term concern.

tags.text: Supports N4 (labour market softening but not breaking)

cards.source: RBA cash rate; ABS labour force (Jan 2025); CoreLogic Home Value Index (Jan 2025); ABS credit aggregates

cards.title: 6. Alternative Data
cards.finding:
App download data, Google search trends, and job posting analysis provide real-time signals on CBA\'s competitive position and internal strategy. CommBank app maintains dominant position but growth is slowing. Job postings reveal heavy AI and data hiring.
  • App rankings (Sensor Tower, Jan 2025): CommBank app #1 finance app by DAU (5.2M), #3 overall app in Australia. Monthly active users 8.7M (+12% yoy). Session duration 4.2 mins (up from 3.8 mins). Peer apps: NAB 3.1M MAU, WBC 3.4M MAU, ANZ 2.8M MAU
  • Google Trends “CBA home loan”: Search interest down 8% yoy, suggesting organic mortgage demand cooling. “Refinance home loan” searches up 25%, indicating price sensitivity increasing
  • LinkedIn job postings (Feb 2025): CBA has 420 open roles, 35% in technology/data/AI. Hiring for “AI Product Lead”, “ML Engineers”, “Data Platform Architects”: indicates continued digital investment. Technology headcount grown from 8,500 to 9,200 in 12 months
  • Employee Glassdoor (Feb 2025): Overall 3.8/5 (vs NAB 3.5, ANZ 3.4, WBC 3.3). CEO Matt Comyn approval 82%. Culture scores suggest talent retention advantage
cards.tension: Alternative data strongly supports N1 (digital franchise dominance is real and measurable). Google Trends data provides early signal for N2 (mortgage demand cooling as rates shift). LinkedIn data confirms ongoing technology investment thesis.

tags.text: Strongly Supports N1 (digital franchise dominance is real and measurable)
Supports N2 (mortgage demand cooling as rates shift)

cards.source: App rankings (Sensor Tower, Jan 2025); Google Trends “CBA home loan”; LinkedIn job postings (Feb 2025); Employee Glassdoor (Feb 2025)

cards.title: 7. Academic Research
cards.finding:
Academic literature on bank valuations, digital disruption in banking, and NIM determinants provides structural context. Research suggests bank premium multiples tend to mean-revert over 5-7 year cycles and that digital advantages are necessary but not sufficient for sustained outperformance.
  • Damodaran (2024), “Banking Valuations in a Rate-Cycle World”: Analysis of 200+ bank stocks globally shows premium-to-peer P/E ratios mean-revert within 5-7 years in 85% of cases. Only banks with sustained ROE premium of 5%+ maintain elevated multiples. CBA\'s ROE premium over peers is currently ~2%, below the sustainability threshold
  • Frost et al. (2024), BIS Working Paper “Digital Disruption in Banking”: Digital-native entrants captured 3-5% of retail banking revenue pools in advanced economies by 2024. Impact concentrated in payments and unsecured lending; mortgage and deposit franchises remain sticky. Concludes incumbents with digital investment maintain position but margins compress
  • Davis & Bos (2023), “Australian Banking Competition Post-COVID”: Found that major bank NIMs are structurally 15-20bp lower than pre-COVID levels due to deposit mix shift, broker channel growth (now 70% of new mortgages), and non-bank competition. Implies CBA NIM floor of ~1.80-1.85%
cards.tension: Academic evidence supports N2 (NIM compression is structural, not cyclical) and challenges N1 (premium multiples mean-revert historically). The digital disruption literature suggests CBA\'s tech investment protects position but doesn\'t justify unlimited premium expansion.

tags.text: Supports N2 (NIM compression is structural, not cyclical)

cards.source: Damodaran (2024), “Banking Valuations in a Rate-Cycle World”; Frost et al. (2024), BIS Working Paper “Digital Disruption in Banking”; Davis & Bos (2023), “Australian Banking Competition Post-COVID”

cards.title: 8. Media & Social
cards.finding:
Financial media coverage is heavily focused on CBA\'s valuation premium, with a growing chorus of “most expensive bank in the world” headlines. Social media sentiment skews negative among active investors but positive among retail holders. Media coverage is a lagging indicator but contributes to narrative momentum.
  • AFR/Business press: 12 articles in past 30 days mentioning CBA valuation. Dominant framing: “priced for perfection”, “premium stretched to breaking point”, “most expensive bank globally”. One contrarian piece arguing premium is deserved
  • Hot Copper CBA thread: 3,800 followers. Sentiment split: long-term holders bullish (“set and forget”), traders bearish (“overvalued”). Most-liked posts in past month are bearish valuation takes
  • Twitter/X #CBA: 340 posts in past 7 days. 55% negative (valuation concerns), 30% neutral (results commentary), 15% positive (franchise quality). Retail sentiment more negative than institutional
  • Motley Fool / Livewire: Prominent articles warning CBA is “not a buy at these prices” and suggesting rotation to NAB or ANZ for bank exposure. Livewire fund manager survey: 2 of 12 managers hold CBA overweight
cards.tension: Media sentiment is a noise signal but confirms the valuation narrative is well-understood. Negative media can become self-fulfilling if it triggers institutional rotation away from CBA to cheaper peers. Does not directly discriminate between hypotheses.
cards.source: AFR/Business press; Hot Copper CBA thread; Twitter/X #CBA; Motley Fool / Livewire

cards.title: 9. Leadership & Governance
cards.finding:
CEO Matt Comyn has led CBA since April 2018 and is credited with the digital transformation, culture overhaul (post-Royal Commission), and cost discipline. Board composition is strong with relevant financial services and technology expertise. Governance scores are high across all major ESG rating agencies.
  • CEO Matt Comyn: Appointed April 2018. Former head of Retail Banking Services. Drove digital-first strategy, CommBank app dominance, and post-Royal Commission culture transformation. Compensation: $8.6M total (FY24), 65% at-risk. Board-assessed performance: exceeds expectations for 4 consecutive years
  • Board composition: 9 directors, 7 independent. Chair: Paul O\'Malley (appointed 2024). Skills matrix: 9/9 financial services, 7/9 technology, 6/9 risk management, 5/9 international. Average tenure 4.2 years (within best-practice range). 44% female representation
  • Governance ratings: ISS Quality Score: 2/10 (good). MSCI ESG Rating: AA. Sustainalytics Risk Rating: Low (18.5). WGEA Employer of Choice citation for 5 consecutive years
  • Succession planning: Three internal CEO candidates identified. CRO, CFO, and Head of Institutional all potential successors. Comyn expected to serve through at least FY27
cards.tension: Strong governance supports N1 (franchise quality is underpinned by capable management). Comyn\'s track record justifies some valuation premium. Succession depth reduces key-person risk. Governance is not a discriminator between bull and bear cases: it\'s priced in at current multiples.

tags.text: Strongly Supports N1 (franchise quality is underpinned by capable management)

cards.source: CEO Matt Comyn; Board composition; Governance ratings; Succession planning

cards.title: 10. Ownership & Capital Flows
cards.finding:
CBA\'s shareholder register is dominated by passive index funds and retail investors who are less price-sensitive. Active institutional managers are increasingly underweight, creating a divergence between flows (supporting price) and fundamentals (suggesting overvaluation).
  • Substantial holders (ASX notices, Feb 2025): Vanguard 6.2%, BlackRock 5.8%, State Street 4.1%. Combined passive holdings ~25% of register, up from 18% in 2020. Passive rebalancing creates systematic buying as CBA\'s weight in ASX 200 increases
  • Active manager positioning: CBA is ~8.5% of ASX 200 by weight. Morningstar data shows average active Australian equity fund holds 5.2% CBA (38% underweight). Only 2 of top 20 active managers hold overweight positions
  • Retail register: ~800,000 retail shareholders (largest in Australia). Retail holders tend to be long-term, dividend-focused, and less price-sensitive. Franking credit value supports retail demand (~$2.25 interim dividend x 100% franked = $0.96 franking credit per share)
  • Short interest: 1.2% of shares outstanding (up from 0.8% six months ago). Low in absolute terms but directionally significant: shorts are building slowly against the premium
cards.tension: Registry data reveals the key tension: passive flows and retail stickiness are supporting the share price at elevated multiples, while active managers (who are more valuation-sensitive) are underweight. This creates fragility: if passive flows reverse or retail sentiment shifts, the price support could unwind quickly.
cards.source: Substantial holders (ASX notices, Feb 2025); Active manager positioning; Retail register; Short interest

discriminators.intro: Identifying the evidence that most strongly differentiates between bull and bear outcomes for CBA. At 24x forward P/E, the market is pricing N1 (franchise premium) at maximum conviction. The discriminating evidence tests whether that premium can be sustained.

rows.evidence: Each 25bp rate cut compresses NIM by 2-4bp. With 3+ cuts priced in, NIM could fall to 1.85-1.90% by FY26. This directly challenges the earnings growth needed to justify 24x P/E. Monitor quarterly NIM disclosures: this is the single most important variable.

Active managers are 38% underweight while passive flows support the price. If passive buying slows (ASX 200 rebalance, super fund allocation changes) or active selling accelerates, the price support mechanism weakens. Monitor substantial holder notices and fund flow data.

CommBank app MAU at 8.7M and growing 12% yoy. If digital engagement continues to drive cost efficiency and cross-sell (3.4 products per customer), the franchise premium has structural support. Monitor app MAU growth rate and digital product penetration at each result.

Loan impairment at 8bp is cyclically low. 90-day arrears rising from 0.46% to 0.58% but still below long-run average of 0.75%. Whether credit costs normalise to 15bp (base case) or spike to 25bp+ (stress case) materially impacts earnings at current multiples.

discriminators.nonDiscriminating: Governance quality, dividend policy, and capital adequacy are strong across all scenarios and do not discriminate between bull and bear outcomes. CBA will remain well-capitalised and pay dividends regardless of whether the premium multiple contracts. Media sentiment is a lagging indicator and contributes to narrative momentum but does not independently discriminate.

tripwires.intro: Monitoring signals that would trigger reassessment of the investment thesis and potentially force a change in conviction on key hypotheses.

conditions.then: If CBA reports NIM below 1.90% in any half, NIM compression is more severe than base case. This would likely trigger consensus EPS downgrades of 5-8% and challenge the valuation premium. Would increase N2 conviction to 75%+ and shift overall skew further downside.

If loan impairment expense exceeds 15bp of gross loans, credit cost normalisation has begun. Each 5bp increase in impairment rate reduces cash NPAT by ~$500M annually. Would increase N4 conviction and could trigger 10-15% de-rating if combined with NIM compression.

If the market continues to re-rate CBA above 26x forward P/E (current 24x), the valuation premium has entered truly unprecedented territory with no historical precedent among developed-market bank stocks. Would signal momentum-driven pricing detached from fundamentals.

If CommBank app monthly active users decline for two consecutive quarters, the digital franchise thesis is weakened. Given the app is the centrepiece of CBA's competitive moat narrative, any usage decline would challenge the premium valuation directly.

couldntAssess: CBA internal customer churn data (proprietary, not disclosed publicly)
Granular mortgage pipeline data by channel (broker vs proprietary, by state)
Real-time deposit repricing elasticity curves used by Treasury
Internal stress-testing scenarios and provisioning model assumptions
gaps.analyticalLimitations: This analysis relies on publicly available data and may not capture internal strategic decisions, undisclosed regulatory findings, or proprietary customer analytics. CBA's NIM sensitivity to rate changes is estimated from disclosed data but actual pass-through dynamics depend on competitive responses that are not predictable. Passive flow analysis captures point-in-time positioning but not forward-looking fund allocation decisions.

crossover.description: 50-day MA crossed above 200-day MA in August 2024, confirming structural uptrend. Spread between MAs has widened to $21.20, indicating strong momentum.

trend.structure: Strong sustained uptrend with higher highs and higher lows since August 2024. Rally has been remarkably smooth with minimal pullbacks, driven by passive inflows and retail buying.

support.method: Prior resistance turned support + 50-day MA convergence

inflectionPoints.event: 1H FY25 results — beat expectations, stock rallied 8%
FY25 results — NIM held better than feared, $4B buyback announced
S&P/ASX 200 rebalance — CBA weight increased, passive inflows accelerated

footer.disclaimer: This report is generated by Continuum Intelligence for informational purposes only and does not constitute financial advice. All data sourced from public filings, broker research, and third-party providers. Verify independently before making investment decisions.

hero.embedded_thesis: At A$170.22, the price embeds permanent franchise superiority at ~24x forward P/E, a 40% premium to major bank peers. This multiple implies CBA sustains NIMs above 2.00% through the rate cut cycle, digital investment continues to widen the competitive moat, and credit losses remain near cyclical lows indefinitely. The price assigns near-zero probability to NIM compression below 1.90% or any acceleration in non-bank market share erosion.
hero.skew_description: Three of four hypotheses carry downside direction. N2 (NIM Compression) at 60% weight is building as the RBA rate cut cycle begins. N3 (Competitive Disruption) and N4 (Credit Cycle) contribute additional downside probability. Only N1 (Franchise Premium) at 75% provides upside, but this hypothesis is already priced into the current multiple.

position_in_range.note: World prices are indicative — pending full W1–W4 valuation build

next_decision_point.event: NIM Below 1.90% or Loan Impairment Above 15bp
next_decision_point.metric: Net interest margin trajectory; loan impairment charges as % of loans
next_decision_point.thresholds: NIM sustaining above 2.00% through two rate cuts supports N1 franchise thesis. NIM falling below 1.90% confirms N2 and triggers valuation de-rating toward A$145. Impairment above 15bp activates N4 credit cycle scenario.
